definitions.definition: to trick somebody or make them believe something that is not true
definitions.sensetop: cheat somebody/somethingcheat somebody out of something

examples.text: She is accused of attempting to cheat the taxman.
We will crack down on people who try to cheat the system.
Many people **feel cheated** by the election process.
He cheated investors out of billions of dollars.
Customers were cheated by unscrupulous retailers.
Many people felt cheated by the government's refusal to hold another referendum.

definitions.definition: to act in a dishonest way in order to gain an advantage, especially in a game, a competition, an exam, etc.

examples.text: Have you ever cheated in an exam?
Have you ever cheated on an exam?
You're not allowed to look at the answers—**that's cheating**.
Anyone caught cheating will be automatically disqualified from the examination.
Why would anyone want to lie or cheat?

definitions.definition: to have a secret sexual relationship with somebody else
to survive in a situation where you could have died

wordOrigin: late Middle English: shortening of escheat (the original sense) ‘land that is given back to the state or the lord if the owner dies without legal heirs’.
